pullRequest.body:
- I setup notation for the first ordinal in each cardinality.
- `œâ‚ÇÅ` is defined as an ordinal, not as an `out` (cf. `MeasureTheory.CardMeasurableSpace`).
- Lemma using the cofinality of `œâ‚ÇÅ`.
- Lemma on the cardinality of ordinal-indexed `iUnion`s in preparation for material on the Borel hierarchy.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
I'm trying to revive a [mathlib3 PR](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/17972) of mine in parts. 

The first one ([Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Defining.20initial.20ordinals/near/338425902)) only involves ordinals and cardinals.

In the old PR, @vihdzp contributed with golfing a proof, and @sgouezel and @alreadydone help me with style during the review process. I should probably have to add (some of) them as coauthors. Nevertheless, I ported this to Lean4 by hand and I might have missed some of the new style conventions.
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alreadydone.

What's the state of this PR? I see "awaiting-review" has been taken off -- does that mean you don't want it to be merged yet @sterraf ?

I'll delegate merging to @alreadydone 

bors d=alreadydone

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Hi,  I removed the label as Junyan had already approved it, and Mario took
a look.

I was just waiting to see if Mario had more comments, but I'd be happy to
have it merged. Thanks!

PST.-

‚Äîsent from mobile

El dom, 3 de sept de 2023, 11:44, Kyle Miller ***@***.***>
escribi√≥:

> What's the state of this PR? I see "awaiting-review" has been taken off --
> does that mean you don't want it to be merged yet @sterraf
> <https://github.com/sterraf> ?
>
> I'll delegate merging to @alreadydone <https://github.com/alreadydone>
>
> bors d=alreadydone
>
> ‚Äî
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6404#issuecomment-1704324339>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AE54AUQK2KVO7YIQPIVLX5LXYSJVLANCNFSM6AAAAAA3GDWIJQ>
> .
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

Ah, ok, just so you know we use "awaiting-review" to signal "the author approves of merging", so your removing it after approval could have meant "the author does not want this merged right now." No need to remove the label if you get reviewer approval.

Thanks!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Do you have any plans to continue porting the Borel hierarchy? That'd be really nice to have!

> Do you have any plans to continue porting the Borel hierarchy? That'd be really nice to have!

Hi! I'm a bit disconnected from this, and also recall some new contributors were working on Descriptive Set Theory. If the [proposed definition at mathlib3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib3/pull/17972) is still sensible and does not interfere with (or better, is of interest to) them, I might find some time to do it in January.
LGTM otherwise

Thanks!

maintainer merge

mathlib4 style
```suggestion
    sup o < œâ‚ÇÅ := by
```

mathlib4 style
```suggestion
    i.card ‚â§ Œ∫ := by
```
BTW, it's also possible to show this is equivalent to  `i < (Order.succ Œ∫).ord`.
Should I add that `_iff`?
You're welcome to! You just need to combine `Order.lt_succ_iff` and `Cardinal.lt_ord`, I think. It may be better to derive `card_le_of_le_ord` from that stronger result.

> You're welcome to! You just need to combine `Order.lt_succ_iff` and `Cardinal.lt_ord`, I think. It may be better to derive `card_le_of_le_ord` from that stronger result.

I added this `card_le_iff`, but I'm not sure how to derive the older result from this (the present proof is rather short; and the statement, simple enough).

Better conform to the variable names in the rest of the file. Please also change the docstring.
```suggestion
lemma card_le_of_le_ord {c : Cardinal} {o : Ordinal} (hi : o ‚â§ c.ord) :
```
You mean the *variable names* in the docstring? Sorry to be pedantic, there were already some comments on the (older) docstring.

golf
```suggestion
lemma omega_lt_omega1 : œâ < œâ‚ÇÅ := ord_aleph0.symm.trans_lt (ord_lt_ord.mpr (aleph0_lt_aleph_one))
```

mathlib4 style + golf
```suggestion
    (hi : i ‚â§ Œ∫.ord) (hŒ∫ : ‚Ñµ‚ÇÄ ‚â§ Œ∫) (A : Ordinal ‚Üí Set Œ≤)
    (hA : ‚àÄ j < i, #(A j) ‚â§ Œ∫) :
    #(‚ãÉ j < i, A j) ‚â§ Œ∫ := by
  simp_rw [‚Üê mem_Iio, biUnion_eq_iUnion, iUnion, iSup, ‚Üê i.enumIsoOut.symm.surjective.range_comp]
```
I would suggest also use the names `c` and `o` here. It's natural to use `i : Ordinal` above where it serves as an index, but not so much here.
Also suggest changing `hi : i ‚â§ Œ∫.ord` to `hi : i.card ‚â§ Œ∫` to makes it more general.
Thanks, I'll do as suggested
This is what I meant: change the variable names in both the statement and the docstring.
Variable names here haven't been changed; do you agree it's better to use `c` and `o` here following the rest of the file?

I'm actually following your suggestions without hesitations---i.e., I agree completely. 

I just added all the proposed commits in one batch and only later I realized that it did not pass CI. (I did not--and do not--know how to make a more comprehensive commit later and add you as a coauthor.)
Also, I realized I didn't remove the `awaiting-review` label before I double check the stuff. 

Btw, did you see Mario's [comments](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.236404.20defining.20initial.20ordinals/near/382512001)? I was a bit concerned but perhaps we can go ahead with this.

> I'm actually following your suggestions without hesitations---i.e., I agree completely.
> 
> I just added all the proposed commits in one batch and only later I realized that it did not pass CI. (I did not--and do not--know how to make a more comprehensive commit later and add you as a coauthor.) 

My plan was to complete the variable renaming and indent styling after committing the first batch.

> I just added all the proposed commits in one batch and only later I realized that it did not pass CI.

No worries!

> I did not--and do not--know how to make a more comprehensive commit later and add you as a coauthor.

Normally you'd just commit yourself and add me in a Co-authored-by line in the PR description.

> Btw, did you see Mario's [comments](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.236404.20defining.20initial.20ordinals/near/382512001)? I was a bit concerned but perhaps we can go ahead with this.

I actually couldn't find where the range of `Cardinal.ord` is used to define initial ordinals; do you know?

> Normally you'd just commit yourself and add me in a Co-authored-by line in the PR description.
>

Done
 
> > Btw, did you see Mario's [comments](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.236404.20defining.20initial.20ordinals/near/382512001)? I was a bit concerned but perhaps we can go ahead with this.
> 
> I actually couldn't find where the range of `Cardinal.ord` is used to define initial ordinals; do you know?

No, I don't, and I guess it's not. I think he meant that adding this particular def was not necessary, or that adding it as an extra layer would be problematic from an API point of view

> Normally you'd just commit yourself and add me in a Co-authored-by line in the PR description.

No longer to do this since you already commited my suggestions (and I also commited). I've removed the line because otherwise my name will appear twice.
Did you forget to change Œ∫ to c here?

:man_facepalming:
Luckily I found another one (hopefully the last)

You can do this but it's longer and depends on `ord_lt_ord` which appears later, so forget about it.
```suggestion
    o.card ‚â§ c :=
  card_le_iff.2 (ho.trans_lt <| ord_lt_ord.2 <| lt_succ c)
```

It may feel a bit redundant to enclose a `namespace ... end` with a `section`, but maybe it's a good way to organize things. (Personally I might just add a comment rather than using a section; sections can be collapsed in VSCode but you may as well collapse the namespace.)
The style I have seen is having a section for each new concept, I was only trying to mimic this. As always, I am open to modification if it is better for mathlib.

This should probably just say
```suggestion
initial ordinal of cardinality `c`, then its cardinal is no greater than `c`.
```
so maybe delegate so we can fix this before merge.
These are some interesting lemmas but I'm also fine with it if you don't want to keep them.
It seems that the first 3 are indeed redundant once the definition layer was stripped, but perhaps the last one is worth keeping. I'll put that one back.

```suggestion
scoped notation "œâ_" o => ord <| aleph o
```
this adds an extra beta redex in uses of the notation, plus using `œâ_` without applying it to something looks weird and confusing

For the first thing, that's simply me not knowing how to use the `notation` command, sorry for that.

For the notation itself, I do not like `œâ_` either; it was a compromise solution [discussed on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Defining.20initial.20ordinals/near/338425902). I would have liked to have a "subscript argument", but from that discussion I understood that it is not possible.

Do you suggest that the `œâ‚Çô` notation be introduced on demand? (Or not at all?)

Let's commit the suggestion and call it a day :) I think Mario is saying that a standalone `œâ_` looks weird but `œâ_ o` looks okay. I think it's definitely reasonable to introduce local notations `œâ‚ÇÅ`, `œâ‚ÇÇ` etc. to make things more readable, but if you want to use the `Ordinal.initial` function rather than just one of its values then you can't possibly fit an arbitrary expression (or even character) into the subscript, and would have to write `œâ_ expr`.
Of course I accept the suggestion, I honestly wanted to know if it was deemed even better not to introduce `œâ_` at all.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(SetTheory): definition of initial ordinals, œâ‚ÇÅ as an ordinal, ordinal-indexed unions
